            I have noticed a few recurring themes and I would like to share what I know about them. Number one, that infinity cannot expand. I consider this to be false, on account of the fact that something cannot be infinite without being expanding. This can be hard to get at all and impossible to fully comprehend the vastness of infinity. Infinity is one of two things. One is a gradually expanding, yet unstoppable number, item, or reaction. In simpler terms, it is something like x=x+1. Or it can be a number or amount of an item that is expanding to fast for us to comprehend. x equals x to the power of infinity. However, BOTH of these are considered impossible in real world terms due to a simple matter of physics. The Law of Conservation of Mass, one of the most respected laws of physics, states that matter cannot be created or destroyed. This means that the universe CANNOT be infinite. It may expand, but theoretically would have an edge made of all of the unused matter converted from the original big bang explosion. The common belief is that, once this matter is used up, the gravity of everything inside of the universe will pull itself towards the center (Which a non-infinite universe would have at the origin point of the big bang) until it lost all outward momentum and started to revert inward toward said center. This would cause a clump of mass in the center and... well, that's unknown. It may condense into the ultimate clump of dark matter, or there may be some huge chemical reaction. This is pretty much unknown, and cannot be known without having all the information in the universe. So, according to this theory, our universe is just a temporary expansion ending with a re-condensing. Morbid as it may seem, this is the current theory. But, on the bright side, if everything is temporary, it gives much more incentive to DO things. Live a little, because any moment could be your last. Have no regrets.

When faced with unobservables, it is both unscientific and illogical to render conclusions according to what cannot, or has not, been observed. In such cases, existing and observable principles are the only guidelines to theoretical conclusions. Thus, we have no reason to believe that causality begins at the Big Bang, and no way of knowing whether the whole universe has a center and is expanding, or not.

Similarly, since the whole of our universe is not observable, and since the answer to whether it is infinite transcends logic, it is mistaken to conclude that the whole universe does or does not have a center.

For this same reason, it is mistaken to conclude the whole universe is expanding. (It may simply be expanding in our region, while remaining a logic-transcending, unexpanding infinity spacially).

There is are two mistakes starting at about 3 minutes of this presentation that claim; 

1) our whole, rather than just our observable, universe has a beginning, 

2) our whole universe does not have a center, and 

3) space is expanding in both the observable and whole universe.

Not being able to observe what happened before the big bang event is not sufficient reason, based on ignorance as it is, to conclude that this event is, in fact, the beginning of the whole universe.

The Big Bang is grounded in General Relativity. GR operates on equations called "metrics," which convert coordinates into distances in spacetime.

Comparing the expansion of the universe to an inflating balloon is an analogy. Analogies are used to take a complicated subject and present it in a form that can be understood by someone without specialized training in the field. 

The point of the balloon analogy is that the expansion of the universe is like the expansion of the *surface* of a balloon: objects on that surface get farther apart even when they are not actually moving and there is no center to the surface.
